AUTHORS: Bird, C; McCleneghan, C
Trait.Name: exploration type
Rationale.Description: Functional diversity was measured by classifying EM morphotypes. Five different exploration types given by Agerer (2001): contact (no emanating hyphae or rhizomorphs), short distance (lots of emanating hyphae but no rhizomorphs), medium distance (sometimes emanating hyphae with rhizomorphs), long-distance (differentiated rhizomorphs up to decime- ters long), and pick-a-back (this type ‰ÛÏpiggy-backs‰Ûù on rhizomorphs of long distance exploration types)

AUTHORS: Chanteloup, P; Bonis, A

AUTHORS: Duru, M; Theau, JP; Cruz, P
Trait.Name: leaf dry matter content
Rationale.Description: Response trait to nutrient resources (Weiher et al. 1999; Wilson, Thompson, & Hodgson 1999). It also responds to defoliation (QuÌ©tier, Lavorel, Thuiller, & Davies 2007; Martin et al. 2009; Cruz et al. 2010) and temperature (Roche, Diaz-Burlinson, & Gachet 2004). Thus we suggest that it may be an integrated and robust indicator that allows a large set of drivers to be filtered.

Rationale.Description: It is a continuous measure of habitat specialisation

Trait.Name: carbon source utilization
Rationale.Description: Are earlier indicators of soil degradation than chemical or physical parameters

AUTHORS: Frainer, A; McKie, BG; Malmqvist, B
Trait.Name: biomass
Rationale.Description: correlates with the metabolic needs of the individuals (Brown et al. 2004) and therefore with their potential impact on ecosys- tem functioning

AUTHORS: Frainer, A; McKie, BG; Malmqvist, B
Trait.Name: habitat preference
Rationale.Description: substrate and flow preference reflect microhabi- tat preferences of each species, which are likely to dictate the conditions under which they operate most efficiently

AUTHORS: Frainer, A; McKie, BG; Malmqvist, B
Trait.Name: water flow velocity
Rationale.Description: substrate and flow preference reflect microhabi- tat preferences of each species, which are likely to dictate the conditions under which they operate most efficiently

AUTHORS: Frainer, A; McKie, BG; Malmqvist, B
Trait.Name: feeding potential
Rationale.Description: characterizes the breadth of feeding mode for each species (leaf shredding, biofilm grazing, particle gathering and/or predacious), allowing for a comparison between more obligatory and generalist detritivores

AUTHORS: Frainer, A; McKie, BG; Malmqvist, B
Trait.Name: emergence period
Rationale.Description: relates to differences in phenology among the distinct species and reflects energy require- ments and allocation across seasons (all our detritivores were insects)

AUTHORS: Gallagher, RV; Hughes, L; Leishman, MR
Trait.Name: dispersal mode
Rationale.Description: is a useful surrogate for the distance a seed can travel in the landscape (Leishman et al. 2000)

AUTHORS: Gallagher, RV; Hughes, L; Leishman, MR
Trait.Name: leaf area
Rationale.Description: is important for water balance and energy budgets, as well as light inter- ception and penetration to lower canopy layers (Parkhurst and Loucks 1972)

AUTHORS: Gallagher, RV; Hughes, L; Leishman, MR
Trait.Name: growth habit
Rationale.Description: Species with woody and herbaceous growth habits differ in their relative growth rates, specific leaf area (leaf dry mass per unit area) and photosynthetic rates (Hunt and Cornelissen 1997), all of which are important for defining how species capture and deploy resources

AUTHORS: Gallagher, RV; Hughes, L; Leishman, MR
Trait.Name: climbing mechanism
Rationale.Description: the type of mechanism employed has been associated with dif- ferences in leaf area, specific leaf mass and leaf nitrogen content (Castellanos et al. 1989). The mechanism used to climb also mediates interactions between climbers and their hosts (DeWalt et al. 2000).

AUTHORS: Krause, B; Culmsee, H
Trait.Name: pollination mode
Rationale.Description: For grassland specialists, the success of pollination is highly dependent on both species characteristics and landscape composition (Dauber et al., 2010). Flowering species which are mainly reliant on insect pollination are most negatively affected by habitat loss and fragmentation (Aguilar et al., 2006).

AUTHORS: Lagomarsino, A; Grego, S; Kandeler, E
Trait.Name: MicroResp CLPP
Rationale.Description: MicroResp-CLPP reflects the size of microbial population present in soil and is strongly linked to the actual microbial capacity to utilize added substrates (Campbell et al. 2003).

Trait.Name: enzyme activity
Rationale.Description: Reflects the activity of living microorganisms

AUTHORS: Laliberte, E; Norton, DA; Scott, D
Trait.Name: leaf N%
Rationale.Description: Leaf nitrogen (N) concentration had the highest loading on the first PCA axis (Laliberte et al. 2012b), which is associated with the fundamental leaf economics spectrum (Wright et al. 2004)

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: body size
Rationale.Description: Species with a larger body size and therefore a decreased surface area to volume ratio may be better able to cope with the greater variability in temperature and humidity associated with recently burnt habitats.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: abdominal scutes
Rationale.Description: NA

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: ballooning
Rationale.Description:
The ability to disperse would be advantageous in colonizing
  recently disturbed habitats.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: heavy sclerotisation of the cephalothorax
Rationale.Description: Reduces wter loss.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: burrowing
Rationale.Description: Species exhibiting this behaviour might have a greater chance of surviving the passage of fire relative to non-burrowing species and therefore occur in greater abundance in recently burnt areas.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: flattened body
Rationale.Description: A flattened body might not confer a survival advantage during burning and the lack of suitable crevices post-fire may inhibit recolonization.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: time to maturity
Rationale.Description: Species with short maturity times would have an advantage in colonizing and reproducing in recently disturbed areas.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: hunting mode
Rationale.Description: NA

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: diet specialization
Rationale.Description: Diet specialization may increase with time since disturbance.

AUTHORS: Langlands, PR; Brennan, KEC; Framenau, VW; Main, BY
Trait.Name: phenology
Rationale.Description: Fire may disadvantage those species with highly specific environmental triggers for mating activity compared with species that can mate anytime throughout the year.

Trait.Name: canopy height
Rationale.Description: Traits reflect aspects of each species' ability to disperse, establish, acquire water and nutrients, and photosynthesize (Weiher et al 1999; Cornelissen et al 2003)

AUTHORS: Lavian, IL; Vishnevetsky, S; Barness, G; Steinberger, Y
Trait.Name: carbon source utlization
Rationale.Description: BIOLOG (BIOLOG, Hayward, Calif.) plate identication method is used for microbial functional diversity determination (Gram-negative). The plates contain substrates of a wide spectrum of carbon sources, which can be metabolized by the microbial population and used for determining functional biodiversity (Biolog 1993). Each GN plate of the 95 substrate wells contains a compiled low-concentration, buffered nutrient medium, a tetrazolium redox dye and carbon substrate.

AUTHORS: Lavorel, S; de Bello, F; Grigulis, K; Leps, J; Garnier, E; Castro, H; Dolezal, J; Godolets, C; Quetier, F; Thebault, A
Trait.Name: height at reproductive maturity
Rationale.Description: The LHS plant strategy scheme, based on Specific Leaf Area (SlA), plant height (h), and seed weight (sW), is a promising analytical framework because it captures key axes in the variation of plant structure and function (Westoby et al., 2002)

AUTHORS: Marteinsdottir, B; Eriksson, O
Trait.Name: specific leaf area
Rationale.Description: Trait related to the established phase of the plant‰Ûªs life cycle (specific leaf area, SLA, and leaf dry matter content, LDMC). High SLA implies thinner and less dense leaf tissue, which is often associated with higher metabolic rates per mass, shorter leaf life span and higher relative growth rate, while low SLA implies denser leaf tissue and slower metabolic rates per mass (e.g. Weiher et al. 1999; Westoby et al. 2002; Cornelissen et al. 2003). Higher SLA values are often found for species in resource-rich environments (Cornelis- sen et al. 2003).

AUTHORS: Marteinsdottir, B; Eriksson, O
Trait.Name: leaf dry matter content
Rationale.Description: Trait related to the established phase of the plant‰Ûªs life cycle (specific leaf area, SLA, and leaf dry matter content, LDMC). Reflects the average density of the leaf tissue. High LDMC indicates tougher leaves that are more resistant to physical hazards than leaves with a low LDMC (Cornelissen et al. 2003).

AUTHORS: Marteinsdottir, B; Eriksson, O
Trait.Name: seed mass
Rationale.Description: Trait related to the establishment phase of the plant's life cycle (seed mass). Small seeds are often produced in greater numbers than large seeds (e.g. Turnbull et al. 1999; Leishman 2001), but large seeds usually contain more resources (e.g. Eriksson 1997; Dalling & Hubbell 2002; Moles & Westoby 2004). Thus small-seeded species are expected to be better dispersers, while large-seeded species are expected to have higher establishment success. In addition, small-seeded species are thought to have a more persistent seed bank (Thompson et al. 1998), a larger seed bank (Dalling & Hubbell 2002; Jakobsson et al. 2006), faster life cycles i.e. reach maturity earlier (Moles & Westoby 2006) and faster initial growth (Turnbull et al. 2008).

AUTHORS: Niu, KC; Choler, P; de Bello, F; Mirotchnick, N; Du, GZ; Sun, SC
Trait.Name: height
Rationale.Description: The Leaf-Height-Seed scheme proposed that three key functional traits‰ÛÓspecific leaf area (SLA), mature plant height and seed size‰ÛÓcould capture the main axes of variation in ecological strategies between species (Westoby, 1998; Westoby et al., 2002). Accordingly, we chose SLA, mature height and seed size to estimate key dimensions of ecological strategies.

AUTHORS: Papatheodorou, EM; Efthimiadou, E; Stamou, GP
Trait.Name: Biolog plate identification method
Rationale.Description: To account for the functional diversity of soil bacteria, the BIOLOG technique has been frequently employed although it is very often assigned lower discrimination power in separating soils. Actually, the BIOLOG tech- nique ignores the catabolic profiles of functionally inactive (resting or dormant stages [18] and non-culturable microorgan- isms) whereas only fast growing microbes are involved
